content.description: Start on the face left of the vertical crack on the Green Bucket.    #1. Climb over the bulge past the small left facing corner to the top.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start on the face left of the vertical crack on the Green Bucket.

content.description: Darn if I know.  Zig, zag, finish the same as Triple A.  Then show me how :)
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Hades Heights, about 15 feet from the downstream end of the trail

content.description: Climb up to and over or around an overhanging block. Then climb the left to right groove that features yellow lichen 2/3 the way up on right facing flakes and edges. If torqued into the groove correctly you can manage a no hands rest at the crux.
content.protection: Standard TR set-up.
content.location: Right of Leonard's Lunacy and left of Butterfly.

content.description: Start same as Leonards Lunacy.   #1. Layback the left edge of Make A Wish face; keep feet on the face.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as Leonards Lunacy.

content.description: Start same as Incipient.   #1. Climb the face between Incipient and Friction Layback.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as Incipient.

content.description: Climb the crack and corner.  Good holds all the way up.
content.protection:
TR: Trees and boulders for toprope anchors 

  Trad: Normal Stopper set, Cams .1-#2
content.location: Last climb before the path ends at the downstream end of Hades Heights

content.description: From AFALCON GUIDE by Eric J. Horst:   "Begin at a 12 foot-high, right facing flake 15 feet to the right of Easy Layback. Climb the flake and face above to a stance. Finish up over the bulge to the top."
content.protection: Trees at the top for TR. Not recommended for trad.
content.location: Hades Heights

climbs.name: Top Roping at Carderock with Tots

content.description:
Carderock is great for little kids, as the descent makes a good challenge for any sized person, and the base is relatively benign, as long as there are firm rules about going near the river bank.   

  There are several excellent places to top rope at Carderock with 3-5 year olds who are just starting out.  (Note that many of the easy regular routes have holds spaced too far apart for tots.)  

  Here are three slightly less than obvious ones:  

  1) Broken Crevice. The Broken Crevice between the Silver Spot face and the Biceps buttress.  A good spot to begin as it starts with ledgey steps, and gets progressively steeper and the last bit can be deceptively challenging for a three year old.   2) Kindergarten Face Easy. Kindergarten Face just left of the nose.  An easy traverse leads to a small left facing groove corner.  Set the carabiners just right (looking down) of this groove, as the final moves above the groove break left slightly to the top of the face.   3) Meenehan's No Hands Slab. A largish very low angle slab just right of Meenehan's Staircase in the alcove up and right of Beginner's Crack alcove.  This low angle face makes a good first challenge for the littlest ones; and if they make it, have them try the steeper face above, as the ledge in between provides a point to stop and regather totlet karma. 

  [If you're hoping to climb with grown-ups on the same rope, it is possible to combine Kindergarten with Spiderwalk; or the Laundry Chute and Yellow Jacket.  Another helpful combo is Green Bucket - Golden Staircase, as the 30 foot section below Green Bucket is easy 4th.]
content.protection:
top rope 

  PS If you're climbing with your tot alone, it is possible to fix a tag line on the back of their harness with the end of the belay rope.  If they get freaked on the way up, or can't figure out how to lower, you can just laundry-rack them back down to the belayer.
content.location: 1) The Broken Crevice between the Silver Spot face and the Biceps buttress.   2) Kindergarten Face just left of the nose.  An easy traverse leads to a small left facing groove corner.   3) A largish very low angle slab just right of Meenehan's Staircase in the alcove up and right of Beginner's Crack alcove.

content.description: Again a nice an easy boulder a couple of obvious holds and easy top out. Enjoy the view!
content.protection: pad but super easy
content.location: past "dont fall on the hikers" Walk into the park and take left it will be on your right

content.description:
Just right of the big 5.4 off-width fissure, carefully climb the groove.  To climb the right crack, go straight up as the groove turns into an  obvious crack above to the top.  To climb the left crack, angle left about 25 feet up following the slanting layback crack-flake. 

  This enjoyable route is long by Carderock standards, and along with its left variation and the two adjoining more difficult routes makes a good option when the rest of the crag is occupied.
content.protection: top rope
content.location: Sterling's Double Cracks can be accessed from below at low water via a ca. 5.6-5.7 traverse downstream just above the water for about 30 feet starting at Trudi's Terror.  Or one can set the top rope - on the pointed and tallest crag about 30-40 feet downstream from Trudi's Terror - and rappel down to a stance (near an obvious off width fissure) which is dry even at regular water height.

content.description: Start at the left diagonal crack, and climb via layback.
content.protection: Toprope with 75 feet of static line.
content.location: 20 feet downstream from the base of the walkdown.

content.description: Start on a ledge and a sidepull about four feet off the ground. Grab a great crimp on top of a triangle block with your right hand. Slap over the arete and find a decent sloper. Cross off the sloper to a great slot and use other slots to top it out.
content.protection: The landing is pretty good but it is on a hill and next to a hike. Be courteous to hikers.
content.location: This climb is on the billy goat C trail about 2/3 of the way through from Carderock. It is also on the same boulder as One Jump and Krypton.

content.description: Silver Spot the common way.Climb Silver Spot to the crux, then use 1/2 pad horizontal flake top to step left away from crux.So, pull up into and step on right facing half moon. Work liebacks at moderate grade to crux, instead of blank right facing super slopers, use left flake top, attempt to match gracefully; like you meant to escape, (throw a Janja kick flare?) finish easy ground (5.11b), and wonder if you will ever climb the straight up slab finish. (5.12d)
content.protection: top rope, but a reasonable ropeless boulder problem with pads.
content.location: Silver Spot slab, 2 m right of Spider Walk. climb Silver Spot to 3/4 height and use left hand crimp to step left.

content.description:
Climb the face by attaining the slight j-shaped groove and smearing in this until it runs out, using progressively smaller face holds to make progressively harder and shorter moves on the face above.  Though the last portion is ridiculously delicate and involved, the lower sections are worth working on anyway. 

  (Little Dave has reputedly done this ankle breaker w/out a rope...)
content.protection: top rope
content.location: The concave face with a large but faint silver spot in it caused by lichen, about five feet right of the Spiderwalk crack.

content.description: Climb the left face of the corner.  The arete is on.  Holds around the corner are off.
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Hades Heights, just behind a big tree, 30 feet from the downstream end of the trail

content.description: On the left as one approaches the Kindergarten descent is the 'Pre-K' boulder.  The 20 ft traverse of this boulder includes at least one 5.7/5.8 move, and three or more passes will begin to tire out the boulderer.  More interesting when there is a big muddy puddle below the boulder.
content.protection: none
content.location: 50 ft. directly behind the tree anchor for 'Kindergarten'

content.description: Start on the face just to the right of Cripple's Crack.  About 2/3 of the way up, the rock slants up and to the left under a roof.  Follow that slant and finish on Cripple's Crack.
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Hades Heights, just after the last turn before the path ends

content.description: Climb the face using toe holds while laybacking the outside corner of the 'Cripple's Cube'.  Continue up easier rock to the tree alcove below Leonard's Lunacy.
content.protection: Watch the ankle twisting root on the left side of the landing.
content.location: Five feet right of Cripple's Face, on the outside of the corner that forms the right side of Cripple's Face.

content.description: Climb the crack (the left of the two here).  There's a small, triangular roof about 2/3 of the way up.  Go around the right side of that.  There's another roof about 3/4 of the way up, and stay to the left of that.  Then it's a slab climb to the top.
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Hades Heights, just as you turn the last corner before the path ends

content.description: Start between Sterlings Twin Cracks and Trudie's Terror.   #1. Climb up from the river through the bulge and to the top.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start between Sterlings Twin Cracks and Trudie's Terror.

content.description: Nubbin Face is a classic beginner's problem.  Wander up the composite face filled with quartz crystals on these and the various face holds to the top.
content.protection: A long, 25ft or more, sling helps one set the top rope anchor on one of the better trees.
content.location: Begins on the face about 20 feet to the right of 'the Crack'

content.description: Start: Low feet with hands on the cubed corner. Work up and to the right on the overhang using crimps and pinches. Once you hit the crack, head up and over to top out. Topping out brings out the V4 in this route.
content.protection: Crash pads and spotters
content.location: Take Billy Goat Trail C from the trailhead 1/4 to 1/2 of a mile. Boulder is on the left side of the trail.The boulder is right next to the trail/almost on top of it. Be cognizant and respectful of hikers coming around the corner of it/people using the trail. Boulder has overhang with slopped dirt surface below it. There is a steep ~10 drop to the river on the other side of the trail across from it. Watch out for poison ivy.  Latitude: 38.9703 Longitude: -77.1995.

content.description: Climb the rounded arete at the base of the walkdown between Jungle Cliffs and Hades Heights.
content.protection: Toprope off the trees. Bring 75 feet of static line.
content.location: Between kindergarten and spiderwalk, on the rounded arete.

content.description:
Climb straight up through the bulge, onto the face, and up to the 3 foot ledge. Proceed to the top.  

  The crux of this climb is moving up over the bulge (at the nipple). The face climbing above the bulge can be made harder by moving left or skipping holds.
content.protection:
Top Rope from several good trees and slingable boulders up top. Bring 100 feet of static line to tie off to trees. 30-50 feet of webbing to sling boulders.  

  There are a few small hex placements up top for backup as well.  

  Don't place cams up top. They've been known to be stolen.  

  It is possible to lead this climb. Stoppers and small cams should do the trick. There is not much pro on the face, but once you reach the ledge you can place several pieces.  

  You can also choose to place pro behind the right side of the bulge in the large crack (medium to large cams), but those placements are dubious at best.
content.location:
This route is best climbed in the summer when the waterline recedes low enough to reach the bottom of the cliffs at the south end of Hades Heights.  

  Where the trail ends (at Trudies Terror), step over the railroad tie wall, walking down 6-7 feet. Start just left of the right-facing corner.

content.description: Start at Trudie's Terror and move right and up through a bump. The traverse will be on big quartz footholds until you are directly below the overlap (this is the nipple). Climb up and over the initial overhang on beautiful quartz crystals.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top
content.location: Start at Trudie's Terror.

content.description: Climb a narrow path between Butterfly and Easy Layback.  The crack is off.  So is the left side of the face.  What's on?  About 2 feet in the middle.
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Hades Heights, about 30 feet upstream from the end of the path.  Find the flake for Easy Layback, and move just left of that.

content.description: Start same as Yellow Jacket.   #1. Climb the groove stemming wide, between Leonards's Lunacy and Yellow jacket. Half way up, move left and follow the thin crack to the top.   Some variations can be done.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as Yellow Jacket.

content.description: Start to the right of a right-facing flake, under an old bolt.  Head straight up the wall.
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Hades Heights at the downstream end, between the Triple A flake and Trudie's Terror

content.description: Thought to have originally escaped left onto what is now the top of Cripples.   Start right of Cripples, scramble to an off balance ledge below a white streak in the rock above.   #1. Climb the left face of the groove onto the ramp. Undercling the overhang; step right and pull the overhang using a thin right crack. Reach the high for this with a balance move.
content.protection: Anchor same as Make A Wish
content.location: Start right of Cripples, scramble to an off balance ledge below a white streak in the rock above. Anchor same as Make A Wish

content.description: Climb the broken low angle crack/slab behind the large tree. This is a good climb for someone who is just starting out.
content.protection: There are places that will take gear, but I’m not sure I’d want to fall. It’s an easy top rope setup up top.
content.location: Located 10’ or so to the climber’s left of Butterfly, behind the large tree.

content.description: Start Low on the left side of the face with a jug and crimp. Cross to a side-pull and pull-through to a another side-pull. Match and get a heel on the edge of the boulder and throw for a sharp sloper. Use slots to get up to the very tip of the boulder and top-out.
content.protection: The landing is flat but is next to a trail so be courteous to hikers.
content.location: This boulder is about 2/3 of the way along billy goat C starting from Carderock. The hike is about ten minutes from Carderock and this boulder is a definitely a must climb if you are looking for some moderate bouldering.

content.description: Easy climb with nice holds.  Starts at the base of a tree.  Good climb for small kids - 5, 6 and 10 year olds climbed it with no problem.
content.protection: Natural anchors at the top.  A large tree to sling and several flakes.  Need good length of static rope (40 ft) and 25-30 ft of webbing.
content.location: The route is actually located in the down climb gully (to the right as you face the rock) in the middle of Carderock area.

content.description: Layback a small and rounded left facing corner about ten feet left of the Sterling's start. Climb up and right (keeping downstream and out of Sterling's Double Crack) towards a hanging tooth overhang, and surmount this overhang (crux) just left of the tooth.  (A more difficult - 5.10 - start can be had by bouldering through the overhanging face further right.)
content.protection: top rope
content.location: About 10 feet downstream of the Sterling's Double Crack start.

content.description: Start at right-facing flake, cross an overhang, then use only hands and feet within a foot-wide zone centered on a hairline crack. Good slabby footwork and balance practice. Locals called it a Carderock classic, thus the rating.
content.protection: Gear required for TR anchor.
content.location: Hades Heights, right side.

climbs.name: If You Have to Climb in Maryland

content.description: Done with a jump start. Thin, technical face climbing up to the ledge. Easy finish to the top.
content.protection: Trees at top, bring a long static rope.
content.location: Directly to the left of Nubble Face.

content.description: It is possible to boulder traverse the entirety of the Hades Heights formation (with feet no more than 4-6 ft off the dirt).  Begin down the Kindergarten face as the usual descent between Hades Heights and Jungle Cliffs, and keep going until Trudie's Terror.  There are difficult - 5.9 or 5.10 - moves between the Nose and Spiderwalk, between the Crack and Nubbin face, between Chris's Goat and Cripple's Crack (crux), and stepping across the bottom of Merv's Nerve. (The crux section between Chris's Goat and the Laundry Chute passing the Cripple's Crack area is known as 'Cripple's Traverse.') If the water is low, keep going to the base of Sterling's Double Cracks and exit up the off-width (5.3 highball) or if it is high, wander up Norris's Nipple (5.4 deep water).  Slightly easier going right to left, though.
content.protection: None
content.location: Start at the top of the Kindergarten Face (West End) or at Trudi's Terror (East End).

content.description: Climb the block left of Nubble Face to a ledge below underclings and side pulls along with slick feet. Move up to the "green bucket" hold and then up and over the overhang. This route at Carderock may not live up to its rating compared to some other classics.
content.protection: This is a boulder problem on top rope.
content.location: Just left of Nubble Face and climber's right from the down climb. Move too far right on the side pulls and underclings and you're on Desperation.

content.description:
Golden Staircase is a somewhat contrived but really fine moderate toprope problem going up the arete or buttress formed by the right side of the Green Bucket-Desperation overhang.  Start on the face just left of 'The Crack' and climb using neither the Crack or the corner to your left straight up until it is possible to traverse 15 feet above to the left side of the buttress.  Climb the small face holds straight up until one can layback right onto the buttress underneath 'Desperation' on the obvious flakes which keep breaking off until one can mantle a big leaning shelf near the top.  The way is partially revealed by the 'golden' lichen giving the climb its name. 

  Variations can be had by continuously trending right onto the steep face above 'The Crack' without touching the crack, and going up that face to the top of golden staircase.  Several 5.8-5.9 problems will be discovered.
content.protection: top rope
content.location: Start on the very small piece of face just left of 'The Crack'.

content.description: An excellent and easy climb for beginners. Climb the corner.
content.protection: Lead climbing is not recommended because the mica schist is slick and friable, and pro pulls out. Bring a 40 m climbing rope and 30m of static line for top-rope anchors. The trees at the top are really good anchors.
content.location: North west corner of Cripple's Crack Area, southern part of Hades Heights.

content.description: Climb up into the hole, sometimes wet, to the right of the incipient overhang, and fiddle around until you can get a hand on the obvious right-facing flange above. Yard on this and layback delicately to the top.  Keep going on the rough rock above.
content.protection: top rope
content.location: Look up to see a large flange five feet left of Incipient Crack and some 15-20 feet right of Nubbin Face.

content.description: A variation of Butterfly. Hands on the left face of the dihedral with feet on the right. Use hand and finger pockets to layback and jam your way to the top on slick footholds.
content.protection: Boulders at the top of the route offer easy and bomber top rope anchors.
content.location: The furthest area downstream at the crag. To the right of Cripple's Crack and to the left Triple A.

content.description:
From AFALCON GUIDE by Eric J. Horst:   "Climb along the hairline crack located just right of Easy Layback and finish up the corner above to the top." 

  The first handful of moves are thin and very crimpy. The crux is a single move about 12 feet up and is what gives this route a 5.10b rating. After reaching the corner, holds are good and it's smooth sailing to the top.
content.protection: Trees at the top for TR. Not recommended for trad.
content.location: Hades Heights

content.description: Start below the bolt(and scar) between TripleA and the corner, same as Mad Dog.   #1. Climb straight up and to the top (and not right like Mad Dog)
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start below the bolt(and scar) between TripleA and the corner.

content.description: Start same as Golden Staircase.   #1. From the low angle area climb up the steep face on the right.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top   Anchor not the same as Golden Staircase.
content.location: Start same as Golden Staircase.

content.description: Start same as Easy Layback.   #1. Climb the face to the right of the Easy Layback crack.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as Easy Layback

content.description: Climb the right-facing flake
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Look for the prominent flake behind a big boulder.  About 20 feet from the end of the path.

content.description: Pretty easy just dont hit anybody if you fall
content.protection: pads
content.location: Follow the anchors to the left. It'll be right along the hiking trail

content.description: There are two distinct moves on this route. First get into the upper undercling (two positive slots right next to each other). Then, working your feet up above the flake, go for the crystals directly above. Don't use anything on the arete. This is a short problem, but rewarding.   A variation is to go left for the bucket of Green Bucket from the undercling.
content.protection: Toprope
content.location: Right of Green Bucket, before the arete.

content.description: Make some difficult moves up past the crystal knobs - using the rib to the right to make it easier - until one crosses Sterling's Double Crack.  Keep climbing past a few pockets straight up the face about 5 feet left of Sterling's Right Double Crack.
content.protection: top rope
content.location: On a face with quartz hold and a largish rib that starts about 7 feet up, about 6 feet downstream of the Sterling's Double Cracks start.

content.description: Start same as Incipient.   #1. Climb the overhang and pull it using handhold 4 feet right of Incipient. This is done by using ubderclings and pinches to pull onto the face above.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as Incipient.

content.description: Start on the face just left of Cripple Crack.  Don't use the crack.  Beyond the arete on the left is definitely off.  I think the arete is off, too, but I'm not positive.
content.protection: Trees and large boulders for toprope anchors
content.location: Hades Heights, just left of Cripple Crack, as you turn the last corner before the path ends

content.description:
This is a great leadable climb. Don't be fooled by that 5.3 rating though, due to heavy traffic the holds are all polished and slick as marbles. 

  According to the guidebook, the first part of the climb you should head up the face climb to the left of the crack, then move into the crack once you're on the easier ground. 

  If you head right up the crack though, it is definitely quite challenging, and feels more like 5.8ish for the first few moves till you're up it. 

  Enjoy the harder start, then scamper up the low angle ramp to the vertical exit. Good fun.
content.protection: Nuts.
content.location: Hades Heights, in the crack upstream from nubble face.

content.description:
Chris's Goat is a Carderock (aka sandbag) 5.7 that ascends the curling edge of the buttress dividing Incipient Crack from Cripple's Crack.   

  Start is the same as Friction Layback, but traverse right under the Incipient overhang to the buttress edge, and carefully layback this to the top, drifting slowly with your feet onto the steeper Cripple's face in order to avoid barndooring your rear end and the rest of you into an undesirable bass-akwards pirouette across the same. 

  (A slightly harder start is possible by beginning on Cripple's Crack and working up and left to join Chris's goat where it reaches the buttress from its traverse under the overhang.)
content.protection: Top Rope slinging the same horns used to set up the Cripple's top rope.
content.location: Same as Friction Layback a few feet right of Incipient Crack.

content.description:
This historic traverse was first completed in the 1940s by Chris Scoredos, Don Hubbard, and Arnold Wexler. Today this route is an R rated adventure. The leader and follower will be exposed to ground fall potential and a fall on gear on this rock is questionable at best. There are multiple incidences of trad gear failing due to rock quality at Carderock.  

  Start: Garbage Chute Corner 

  P1: Climbing 20 feet up the Garbage Chute corner, then traverses right across the the cliff (downstream) at the obvious horizontal break in the cliff. Continue past the corner of Trudie's Terror. Belay at the scrubby pine. (~150ft) 

  P2: Down climb the easy ramp/corner. Make an exposed move over the water to gain the foot ledge. Continue out the ledge until you are below a licheny, slightly vegetated crack (V1). Climb the crack to top of the cliff.  

  V1: from the vegetated crack, continue traversing right and turn a corner.  (this variation is the historical description but has not been climbed/verified recently)
content.protection:
Bring a single rack to 4" and a few long runners. 

  This route is runout and traverses, both the leader and the follower will be exposed to ground fall potential on the first pitch.  

  The nature of the rock of Carderock is such that trad gear cannot be relied upon. There are multiple reports over the years of trad gear failing due to the soft, flakey nature of the rock.
content.location: Start at Garbage Chute (the easy looking corner to the right of Cripple's Crack}

content.description:
This thing is EPIC! The Carderock Low Traverse is a ~400-foot endurance climb with two 5.12 cruxes, three 5.11 cruxes, and endless beautiful 5.9/5.10 climbing. ...and it almost never gets more than 4 feet off the ground!

 Here is a video that summarizes the route: youtube.com/watch?v=ZgOm9l9…

 The Carderock Low Traverse is my best attempt to traverse as much of the Carderock formation as possible, while staying as low to the ground as possible. Currently, it doesn't traverse the entire cliff, but is crosses about 50% of Jungle Cliff and the entirety of Hades Heights, for something like 400-feet of fairly sustained climbing. The crux is perhaps v4 or v5, but I think of it as a mid 5.12 due to the length.

 While I have sent the currently described version of this traverse (starting from the X-face and working right), The Complete Carderock Low Traverse (a traverse of the entire cliff) is still a work in progress. However, I am not sure that it is possible to climb it in the same "bouldering style" of the climb described here. The terrain to the left of the X-face has one section that seems impossible to climb (at least for me) without a rope.

 Anyway, here is the beta: Start at the left side of the X-face (just left of "The X") and start traversing to the right. Stay low around the corner, climbing the awesome v4 boulder problem, Tea and Scrumpet (the first crux of the route, and perhaps the crux for those who don't have it mercilessly wired). Continue across the face, staying reasonably low. Shortly past Beginner's Crack, round the blunt corner, passing the tree. Traverse right and upwards, climbing an awkward boulder problem called Shinbone. We call it 11+, but it's never once felt that easy. Your feet get very close to the boulder, but keep then from touching it! Round the sharp arete and rest for a while. Continue traversing right across somewhat blocky terrain. There is a ~5.10 crux here with difficult-to-find holds. Also, there is a steep section where you cross over a deep pit with some fall potential (5.9R). Finally, right before the walkdown is what I consider to be the crux of the traverse. You round a corner and scrunch down very low to the ground, slapping a flat ledge (5.12c). Then climb upwards and kick back to the boulder behind you. After this, continue traversing right to the end of the cliff. Basically, you just follow the Hades Heights Girdle Traverse, but staying as low to the ground as possible. I go kinda high at the rounded corner close to the river (Cripple's traverse crux), and it feels about v3, but lower variations exist at harder grades.
Start at the crack in the slab and climb up the arete to the top. Steep and mildly desperate. This is basically a boulder problem 15' off the ground.
content.protection: Top Rope (a tough one to set but maybe why this went unclimbed for the past 80 years)
content.location: First climb on the "Camp Buttress". Located between Biceps and the Green Bucket wall.

content.description: Climb up the short slab to the undercling and onto the face. Follow the quartz bulge to the top. One of the coolest holds in all of Carderock is found on this route imo.
content.protection: Top Rope
content.location: Between Can't Permit and Camp Daze, on the small buttress between Biceps and The Green Bucket wall.

content.description: Kinda a choose your own adventure and maybe a bit harder than 5.3 depending on how you go. Its easier to the outsides of the line and harder up the gut. Start about 10 feet left of Green Bucket and Bad Rock.
content.protection: Top Rope
content.location: Third climb on the "Camp Buttress".

content.description: Fun climb that poses a couple of little cruxes, mostly thin with crimpers: Note the holds on the corner are off.  A common variation of this climb is to use only hand holds on the corner, and feet on the slab.
content.protection: Large Boulders and trees at the top for anchors
content.location: To the left at the bottom of the down climb, the climb follows the inside of a corner formed by the rock, starts just to the left of a large boulder.

content.description: Start same as The Bulge.   #1. Climb the crack to the left of The Bulge
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as The Bulge.

content.description:
From the hole five feet up climb straight up over the bulge above on face holds without using either the flange formed by Friction Layback to your right or the crack angling up to the left which divides the Bulge from Nubbin Face to your left.  Challenging high steps on little crimpers and nubbles. 

  The crack angling up to the left from the hole is called 'Bulging Crack' (5.6), and makes a good escape or easier line of ascent worthwhile on its own terms.
content.protection: top rope
content.location: Same start as Friction Layback just to the right of Incipient Crack.

content.description:
I'm not sure if this boulder has a name or named routes.  Perhaps someone who knows can pass on the info and I will update this.  It clearly had chalk from previous climbs on it.  There's maybe 2-3 routes on it.  It's the first large rock you come to heading west on section B of the Billy Goat trail.  Not far from where the trail leaves the C&O Canal and right when you get down to the river. 

  The main route starts on the climbers right as a sit start.  Work up the small incuts and ledges working up and left.  Find a place to top  out.  It gets reachier at the top and much harder the further you try to work left. 

  On the far left side of the boulder there might be another short route.  Use the two obvious ledges for some dynamic moves up to a grippy sloper on top.  Topping out is a bit nasty.  I tried to clean up some of the vines on top. 

  Any info on this area would be appreciated.
content.protection: Crash pad makes landings nicer.
content.location: This is the first large rock you come to as you get down to the river heading west on the Billy Goat trail. As you come down hill to the river look back right.

content.description: Start same as Biceps.   #1. Step up below the lip of the overhang. Step right, and use an under cling to pull the overhang and reach the crack.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as Biceps

content.description: Start same as Bicep.   #1. Climb the left side of the overhang, 50 feet down-stream of the walk down.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start same as Bicep

content.description: Start at the lower edge of the Biceps overhang.   #1. Move right, up face, using laybacks and a mantle finish.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top.
content.location: Start at the lower edge of the Biceps overhang.

content.description: Easy climbing to the overhang just left of The Crack at Hades Heights.  This route is really a boulder problem 15 ft off the ground.  Pull through the center of the overhang.  Climbing is much easier on the right (exploiting the arete).
content.protection: Build a TR anchor at the top.

content.description: Carderock’s downstream end. Beginning at the scramble down and Kindergarten, Spiderwalk and Silver Spot and ending where the river meets the rock at Trudy’s Terror.  At Biceps overhang, shade trees give way to open skies and warm south aspect faces of Hades Heights. Routes continue down with Green Bucket, Nubble Face then turning a corner at Cripple Crack, finishing with Merv’s Nerve, Easy Lieback and Finger Nail. Hades Heights is adjacent the Potomac River offering views up and downstream and across to Vaso Island. Generations of climbing has rendered the base of the wall bare ground and some of the holds polished. A 15 m length of anchor rope protects the top roping with tree and block anchors.
